My question here is why does it matter what the character encoding of
the site is? If the URL is URL encoded then there isn't an issue: the
URL will be encoded at the byte level, and all is fine.

We faced a similar problem to this when we worked with Lycos to move
their systems to Asia: it was common for Japanese documents to include
URLs that contains Japanese text in them in multiple encodings:
someone authoring a page on Windows (which uses CP932, a Shift JIS
variant) might paste a URL or pathname from a Unix system (which is
using EUC-JP). If you weren't careful when extracting the URL then the
characters would get munged and a subsequent crawl would fail.

The cure here was, in part, to URL encode every URL before doing any
other character conversions on the original documents. Heritrix is not
doing this (character conversion), but it should be URL encoding the
URLs if it isn't, IMHO.
